awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Chemical Transformations Enabled by Flow Chemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
In this CAREER project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Beeler of the Department of Chemistry at Boston University is developing new chemical methods utilizing flow chemistry.  Traditionally, chemical transformations have been carried out in batch reactors such as flasks and beakers.  Instead, the Beeler lab carries out reactions by continuously flowing reagents inside of tubing. This approach may lead to significantly more efficient methods for synthesizing molecules with applications in human health, materials science, and agriculture.  The Beeler lab is involved in efforts to bring science education to high school students in the Boston area.  This award supports the development of outreach activities including a science summer camp for local high school students.

The research projects focus on three reaction classes that are significantly enabled by flow chemistry.  Photochemistry may be considered one of the most powerful complexity-generating reaction classes available to chemists.  When utilizing a flow chemistry platform, it may be possible to overcome issues inherent to batch photochemical reactions, such as long reaction times, poor reproducibility, and difficult scalability. This aspect of the project explores a number of powerful photochemical reactions such as [2+2]-photocycloaddition, reactions of photoinduced phenyl cations, and photoinduced electron transfer reactions.  Electrochemical reactions are often underutilized and can be difficult to optimize and scale.  This project develops a practical and scalable electrochemical flow platform that is utilized in the development of oxidative coupling of phenols.  Many examples of flow chemistry utilize highly toxic and/or reactive species or reactions under extreme conditions.   This project focuses on generating and utilizing highly reactive diazoalkanes in complexity-generating reactions.  In addition to this research, the educational outreach focuses on developing a science summer camp at the high school level for students from disadvantaged backgrounds.  New laboratory experiments are being developed to introduce flow chemistry into the undergraduate organic chemistry laboratory curriculum at Boston University.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Photochemical 2+2 Cycloadditions in Flow. Our studies on the [2+2]-photocycloaddition of cinnamates in flow led several major advances outlined below. We established that biphasic segmented flow can significantly increase the rate of the reaction reach a throughput approaching 10g/24hr. Ultimately this is a paradigm of flow photochemistry that could improve many challenging reactions and will have a broad impact. We also developed the first photochemical method for the synthesis of heterodimeric truxinates. Finally, we developed a highly scaleable templated dimerization to access beta truxinates in kilogram/day scales.

 

Photoredox Generation of Carbonyl Ylides. We developed a visible light photoredox mediated reaction of diary epoxides to afford carbonyl ylides intermediates that can be intercepted through a subsequent [3+2] cycloaddition. The project led to several advances in photoredox catalyst design and synthetic application of diraryl epoxides. Specifically, we designed a new pyrylium catalyst that has the highest reported redox potential of any visible light organic catalyst. The new catalyst enabled us to greatly expand the scope and utility epoxide cycloaddition reaction to afford dihydro and tetrahydrofurans. This visible light mediated reaction can be done in flow and provides access to gram quantities of the biaryl tetrahydrofurans that have been used to developed one-step or two-step procedures to synthesize every subfamily of the classical lignans, including 2,3 desmethoxy seco-isolintetralin, pycnanthulignene C, and methyl piperitol.

 

Development of the Buchner Reaction with Diazoalkanes in Flow. We have developed a continuous flow intermolecular Buchner reaction that significantly expands the scope and utility of this reaction. We have also demonstrated that the reaction can be carried out with a  chiral catalyst to afford cycloheptatrienes with enantiomeric excess up to 96%, which was the first example of an asymmetric intermolecular Bucher reaction. We have also developed a visible light mediated ring expansion of N-heteroaromatic substrates to afford azapines which is the first example of such an aza-Buchner reaction. This reaction provides a more efficient and diverse route to these important chemotypes.

 

Training and Outreach. The project has supported graduate students and undergraduate students who have developed new reaction methodologies and have become acknowledged experts in the area of flow chemistry.  This is a unique skill that is highly sought in the pharmaceutical industry. We developed an undergraduate laboratory experiment that has been fully integrated into our organic chemistry curriculum, providing students with exposure and experience in a cutting-edge technology. The project has allowed us to have significant efforts toward outreach through the REU, GROW, and Upward Bound programs. We have hosted 6 REU students, 3 GROW students, and carried out numerous workshops through the Upward Bound program. 

 


Last Modified: 10/12/2021
Modified by: Aaron Beeler
